After many years of NASA research into sonic booms, this aircraft was designed to reduce the sonic boom reaching the ground to where it may be acceptable to the general public. However, one unclassified exotic aircraft currently in fabrication by them is the X-59 Low Boom Flight Demonstrator aircraft, designed and built under a NASA contract. After many years of NASA research into sonic booms, this aircraft was designed to reduce the sonic boom reaching the ground to where it may be acceptable to the general public. If so, the current restrictions on supersonic flight over land may be lifted to allow supersonic passenger transports to fly over land. United Airlines has already placed orders for a small fleet of supersonic aircraft.

Answer: I worked at LM for 25 years.LMC is probably the largest defense contractor in the world today. They’ve got some 120,000+ employees world-wide with the corporation divided into Business Areas of multiple companies in each Area1)Aeronautics - what most people think of in regard to LM. Currently they are the lead contractor for the F-35, (also known as the JSF, Joint Strike Fighter) which will be manufactured in appropriate modifications for the Air Force, Navy, and Marines. But LM also builds the F-16 and F-22 as well as C-130 Hercules (the most successful military cargo aircraft) and several otI worked at LM for 25 years.LMC is probably the largest defense contractor in the world today. They’ve got some 120,000+ employees world-wide with the corporation divided into Business Areas of multiple companies in each Area1)Aeronautics - what most people think of in regard to LM. Currently they are the lead contractor for the F-35, (also known as the JSF, Joint Strike Fighter) which will be manufactured in appropriate modifications for the Air Force, Navy, and Marines. But LM also builds the F-16 and F-22 as well as C-130 Hercules (the most successful military cargo aircraft) and several others. Part of LM’s Aero capability includes The Skunk Works, famous for cutting edge, super-secret technology development (some of the most famous being the U-2, the F-117 Stealth Fighter-used extensively in Desert Storm-and the SR-71 Blackbird (the fastest and highest piloted aircraft ever made).2) Space - As the name suggests, LM is in the business of space exploration, participating in most NASA projects, such as sending the rovers/probes to Mars, developing launch systems, satellites, and of course, military space systems, weather systems, etc. LMC is part of the United Launch Alliance, a joint business venture they co-launched with Boeing.3) Missiles & Fire Control - this area is involved in developing missile weapon systems for use on land, combat personnel, and ship systems, including theater combat management and integration systems. They are also involved in the management and development of Energy systems, including nuclear weapons research and nuclear power and management4)Rotary and Mission Systems - provides surface, air, and undersea systems mostly for the US, but also for some international customers. This includes their latest acquisition of Sikorsky Aircraft (maker of advanced helicopters, etc.)This should give you an overall sense of the scope of activities and influence they have. But there is much more in the way of “smaller” projects, such as developing package-sorting systems for the Post Office, Dead-Beat Dad tracking systems, highway/street monitoring and ticketing systems, fingerprint identification systems for the FBI, and large-scale IT systems and management, and much more.

Heat your water with solar collectors.Then you have to consider if you’d want to spend most of your days with people who like that sort of thing.You have to ask yourself why you want to be an engineer. Are you attracted to the pay? To the career opportunities? Some perceived level of prestige or respect (cough)? Do you like problem solving? Are you good at STEM subjects?I would say no. If you don’t have an interest in technology, then engineering is probably not a good career path. But people design things who aren’t engineers. UX UI designers, product designers, etc. They need to understand human nature and ergonomics. It can be as much art as science. But so many modern careers need to at least tolerate technology.“An optimist sees the glass as half full. A pessimist sees the glass as half empty. An engineer sees the glass as being twice as large as it needs to be.”If you think this joke is funny, then maybe there is a stirring of interest you haven’t recognized yet. If you don’t or didn’t think of it as a joke, well…

Answer: Mechanical calculators.Of course, the most well-known of these is the Antikythera Device.This machine was found in a shipwreck in 1901 off Greece and is believed to have been made in 150 BC or thereabouts. At the time of its loss in the shipwreck, the device was pretty old, believed to have been in use for at least 60 years. The device, made of brass, has a number of moving parts and dials like a clock that when operated would describe the motion of the planets and the moon on certain dates. It was made in Greece and uses a level of multiple technologies thought not possible at the time includMechanical calculators.Of course, the most well-known of these is the Antikythera Device.This machine was found in a shipwreck in 1901 off Greece and is believed to have been made in 150 BC or thereabouts. At the time of its loss in the shipwreck, the device was pretty old, believed to have been in use for at least 60 years. The device, made of brass, has a number of moving parts and dials like a clock that when operated would describe the motion of the planets and the moon on certain dates. It was made in Greece and uses a level of multiple technologies thought not possible at the time including precision metallurgy, screws, toothed gears, gradation of dials, precision metal construction and so on. It wouldn’t be until about 1453 that any comparable technology would be re-invented in the use of mechanical clocks and most of these were made out of carved wood because the precision metallurgy and construction needed to make them was rare or non-existent (John Harrison’s church clocks made in the 1700s were made entirely of wood including the self-lubricating lignum-vitae and still tell accurate time today).ElectroplatingWhile modern electroplating goes back to 1805 based on the 1799 invention of the voltaic pile, or “battery” as we call it today, it has been shown that it is possible that ancient Persians (today, Iranians) were using electroplating as early as 224 BC. The device has been shown in modern times on numerous occasions to be capable of electroplating objects if grape juice and a ground-up beetle were used to create a weak electric current. Although experiments have shown this to be possible, there are many missing elements that would have been needed including drawn copper or gold wire, insulators and connectors. So there is still some doubt about it as an electroplating machine. In addition, there are no known electroplated objects extant from that period so there is no product that demonstrates the machine was used or even possible. This information suggests the knowledge and use of electricity which wasn’t commonly known to exist until Ben Franklin proved it in 1752 showing that lightning was actually electricity. From there, a torrent of discoveries were made by Volta, Faraday and others.Stone ToolsStone tools were among the first man-made manufactured objects but it requires a loosely defined definition of “man”. Some of these tools go back to about 1.7 million years and some even further. One of the oldest is the Tanzanian Oldowan tool “industry” (in this use, the word “industry” has a different meaning than we use it on a regular basis). In addition, this was followed by the more complex Acheulean tool industry in France about the same time period. The ancients used stone tools for cutting, pounding and scraping and sought out particular types of stone for the way they broke at certain fracture points, one of the most desirable being obsidian, one of the most common being flint. Today, the sharpest blades in the world are still made of obsidian which can be sharpened to single molecule thickness on the edge.Of course everyone talks of Hero’s Aeliopile or early steam engines. These machines were for demonstration and never did any kind of useful work.There is an opposite and associated question, which technologies are NEWER than they appear and this is equally fascinating.People take for granted certain things such as the “chimney”. While the chimney seems pretty simple to us, the first use of residential chimneys wasn’t until a king in England put one in his castle in 1185 with a smoke hood to evacuate the smoke from his Great Room. Until then, large campfires were made right on the stone (or dirt) floor and the smoke escaped from the windows. It was a horrible price to pay for heat. Even then, residential chimneys in houses were not common until the 1600s. The Pilgrims coming to America had no chimneys in their homes - just a hole in the roof to allow smoke to escape. Certain laws were passed requiring “mud daubing” in homes to prevent sparks from setting the wood on fire. When the first chimney was invented, in the castle in Yorkshire it was the wonder of the age and people and scientists came from all over to investigate the modern invention and its obvious improvement over the current method of allowing the house to fill with smoke just to get heat. Note that building a chimney that drafts properly is not just a matter of stacking stone in a cylinder but requires other elements to make it work efficiently.Another more “modern” invention we take for granted today is the fireplace fire grate. This simple device was invented in 1678 in Germany by Prince Rupert and was a major step forward in heating. All at once, it lifted the fire off the floor and allowed enveloping ventilation that produced more fire, more heat, less smoke and more light. By the 1700s, this was still considered “advanced technology” but homes everywhere implemented all manner of fire grates and cranes and cooking implements to take advantage of the fire grate.Another technology that is much newer than most people think is the “fork”. While it was invented in Turkey in about 450 AD it was rarely used, thought to be an affectation of homosexuals and was banned by the church for awhile as blasphemy, since god gave us “fingers”. It was not until the world’s first tourist, an Englishman by the name Thomas Coryat who traveled Europe and wrote a “blog” of his adventures. He brought the fork to England in 1611 and after awhile it became the plaything of the elite, and each guest brought his own fork in a special box. In those days, forks had only two tines. The four-tine fork we know today did not come into common usage until the mid-1800s.

Answer: There are a great many private research companies in the United States that have begun with just a few people with a lot of talent. With a back ground of solid achievement and an ability to explain their objectives, those few have the potential to do it.It may start with the company they presently work with. Their company may be willing to fund their firm in return for a share of their stock.It may start with a single wealthy benefactor that will supply a working space.Venture capital firms are always looking for small organizations that work in specialties they are already invested in. LocatiThere are a great many private research companies in the United States that have begun with just a few people with a lot of talent. With a back ground of solid achievement and an ability to explain their objectives, those few have the potential to do it.It may start with the company they presently work with. Their company may be willing to fund their firm in return for a share of their stock.It may start with a single wealthy benefactor that will supply a working space.Venture capital firms are always looking for small organizations that work in specialties they are already invested in. Locating an appropriate funding organization like that may require some looking, but could end up being their best backer.Neglect not a partial government contract for a specific goal. The armed services, CDC, NASA, NIH and NOAA are constantly searching for organizations with the ability to solve a tough scientific problem.Foreign states with a windfall of cash have been known to prowl through America, looking for new companies to invest in. In the early 1970s, Middle Eastern countries with an excess of oil wealth did that, and many research laboratories sponsored by these “Petrodollars” are thriving to this day.Oddly enough, other private research firms also sponsor work in specialties they have cash for, but no experienced in.If all this sounds like you will be spending a lot of time looking for money, you would be correct. Your presentations might be well received, but ditch the terms “startup” and “impossible scifi futuristic inventions”: they are so twentieth century, and have the stink of possible failure.

Answer: If you had a lot of money, you could try starting a small museum that collects odd objects. There are museums like this already in Europe and parts of the United States. However, you may need a special license and permission from the state. You might have to run it as a non-profit. And, you may not like this idea anyway, but at least it doesn't require access to physics labs or cutting-edge technology. Another idea is to buy eccentric inventions and turn it into a sculpture museum, but you would probably end up being conned out of a lot of money. People would sell you modified washing machinesIf you had a lot of money, you could try starting a small museum that collects odd objects. There are museums like this already in Europe and parts of the United States. However, you may need a special license and permission from the state. You might have to run it as a non-profit. And, you may not like this idea anyway, but at least it doesn't require access to physics labs or cutting-edge technology. Another idea is to buy eccentric inventions and turn it into a sculpture museum, but you would probably end up being conned out of a lot of money. People would sell you modified washing machines with creative writing, and at that point you may as well just invent the whole thing yourself at an exponentially smaller cost. A much cheaper way to go is to start a website collecting writings on arcane and bizarre subjects, but you may have trouble getting permission from interesting authors. The really good authors want to be fairly presented. They don't want to be on a crappy site, and they might even want money for their work. At that point you would do better to have a product like a book instead of a website or museum, but even if it's sort of okay you may not be able to sell many copies unless you're already famous.In short, if someone's not doing it already, it might not be worth any money. Most of the time if it could have been collected into a book from popular sources, someone has already done something similar, like News of the Weird, and Ripley' s Believe it or Not. You might enjoy those books, but they're obviously not worth money to you.However, here is some rare information about divine artifacts, in case you're interested:Nathan Coppedge's answer to What are some divine artifact?

Old sales price.Vandals wait for things to come to the head to get going. Police don’t arrive to a crime scene in good times. In bad times you’d need to pay them up front to do their work.Another business that went belly up.
